description: Borrowed from Latin extortus, past participle of extorquere (“to twist or wrench out, to extort”); from ex (“out”) + -tort, from torqueō (“twist, turn”).

verbs.description: extort (third-person singular simple present extorts, present participle extorting, simple past and past participle extorted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To take or seize from an unwilling person by physical force, menace, duress, torture, or any undue or illegal exercise of power or ingenuity.
examples: to extort contributions from the vanquished
to extort payment of a debt

entries.meaning: (transitive, law) To obtain by means of the offense of extortion.
(transitive and intransitive, medicine, ophthalmology) To twist outwards.
